data.context: One dollar and eighty-seven cents. That was all. And sixty cents of it was in pennies. Pennies saved one and two at a time by bulldozing the grocer and the vegetable man and the butcher until one's cheeks burned with the silent imputation of parsimony that such close dealing implied. Three times Della counted it. One dollar and eighty-seven cents. And the next day would be Christmas.
data.question: How much money did Della have?

data.context: There was clearly nothing left to do but flop down on the shabby little couch and howl. So Della did it. Which instigates the moral reflection that life is made up of sobs, sniffles, and smiles, with sniffles predominating.
data.question: What did Della do when she realized she didn't have enough money?
data.answer: She flopped down on the shabby little couch and howled.

data.context: The 'Dillingham' had been flung to the breeze during a former period of prosperity when its possessor was being paid $30 per week. Now, when the income was shrunk to $20, the letters of 'Dillingham' looked blurred, as though they were thinking seriously of contracting to a modest and unassuming D.
data.question: Why did the letters of 'Dillingham' look blurred?
data.answer: Because the income had shrunk from $30 per week to $20, making 'Dillingham' less fitting for their modest status.

data.context: Now, there were two possessions of the James Dillingham Youngs in which they both took a mighty pride. One was Jim's gold watch that had been his father's and his grandfather's. The other was Della's hair.
data.question: What were the two possessions that the James Dillingham Youngs took pride in?
data.answer: Jim's gold watch and Della's hair.

data.context: So now Della's beautiful hair fell about her, rippling and shining like a cascade of brown waters. It reached below her knee and made itself almost a garment for her.
data.question: How long was Della's hair?

data.context: Where she stopped the sign read: 'Mme Sofronie. Hair Goods of All Kinds.' One Eight up Della ran, and collected herself, panting. Madame, large, too white, chilly, hardly looked the 'Sofronie.'
data.question: What was the name of the shop where Della sold her hair?
data.answer: Mme Sofronie. Hair Goods of All Kinds.

data.context: 'Twenty dollars,' said Madame, lifting the mass with a practised hand. 'Give it to me quick' said Della.
data.question: How much money did Della get for selling her hair?

data.context: She found it at last. It surely had been made for Jim and no one else. There was no other like it in any of the stores, and she had turned all of them inside out. It was a platinum fob chain simple and chaste in design, properly proclaiming its value by substance alone and not by meretricious ornamentation–as all good things should do. It was even worthy of The Watch.
data.question: What did Della buy for Jim?

data.context: Jim drew a package from his overcoat pocket and threw it upon the table. 'Don't make any mistake, Dell,' he said, 'about me. I don't think there's anything in the way of a haircut or a shave or a shampoo that could make me like my girl any less. But if you'll unwrap that package you may see why you had me going a while at first.'
data.question: What was Jim's reaction to Della's haircut?
data.answer: He said that nothing could make him like her any less, and then asked her to unwrap the package.

data.context: 'Dell,' said he, 'let's put our Christmas presents away and keep 'em a while. They're too nice to use just at present. I sold the watch to get the money to buy your combs.'
data.question: What did Jim do to buy Della's present?
data.answer: He sold his watch to buy her combs.

data.question: How much money did Della have after counting it three times?

data.context: Della sank down onto the worn-out little couch and burst into tears, feeling hopeless about her lack of funds.

data.answer: She sank down onto the couch and burst into tears.

data.context: In better times, the 'Dillingham' part of their name had proudly waved in the wind, back when Jim earned $30 a week. Now, with an income of only $20 a week, the letters seemed to blur as if wanting to shrink to a more humble 'D.'
data.question: Why did the 'Dillingham' part of their name seem blurred?
data.answer: Because Jim's income had decreased from $30 per week to $20 per week.

data.context: The two prized possessions of the James Dillingham Youngs were Jim's inherited gold watch, which had belonged to his father and grandfather, and Della's beautiful hair.

data.answer: Jim's gold watch and Della's hair.

data.context: Della stopped at a shop with a sign that read 'Mme Sofronie. Hair Goods of All Kinds.' She took a deep breath, ran up the stairs, and collected herself before entering.

data.answer: 'Mme Sofronie. Hair Goods of All Kinds.'

data.context: Madame Sofronie inspected Della's hair with a practiced hand and offered her twenty dollars for it. 'Give it to me quick,' Della replied.

data.context: After searching every store, Della finally found the perfect gift for Jim. It was a simple and elegant platinum fob chain, one that suited the value of his prized watch.

data.context: Jim pulled a package from his overcoat pocket and placed it on the table. 'Don't worry, Dell,' he said. 'No haircut or shave could make me love you less. Open the package and you'll understand why I was taken aback initially.'
data.question: How did Jim react to Della's haircut?
data.answer: He reassured her that he loved her no matter what and asked her to open the package.
